subject: Critical Thinking
title: Statistical Reasoning: Numbers as Evidence
description: A quick, practical guide to Statistical Reasoning: Numbers as Evidence.

hook.text: '9 out of 10 dentists recommend...' Recommend what? Compared to what? Asked how? Statistics need context.

buildup.text: Statistical reasoning is formalized induction ‚Äî drawing conclusions from numerical data.

discovery.text: Good statistical reasoning asks: sample size? Selection bias? Confounding variables? Margin of error?

twist.text: 'Correlation does not imply causation' is the most important sentence in statistics. Ice cream doesn't cause drowning.

climax.text: Most misleading statistics aren't wrong ‚Äî they're presented without the context needed to interpret them.

punchline.text: Numbers don't lie. But they omit very strategically.

quiz.question: What does 'correlation does not imply causation' mean?
options: Two things occurring together doesn't prove one causes the other
